revision.text:
'''3DMark''' is a [[computer benchmark]]ing tool created and developed by [[UL (safety organization)|UL]], (formerly [[Futuremark]]), to determine the [[Performance test (assessment)|performance]] of a computer's 3D graphic rendering and CPU workload processing capabilities. Running 3DMark produces a 3DMark score, with higher numbers indicating better performance. The 3DMark measurement unit is intended to give a normalized mean for comparing different PC hardware configurations (mostly [[GPU|graphics processing unit]]s and [[CPU|central processing unit]]s), which proponents such as gamers and [[overclocking]] enthusiasts assert is indicative of end-user performance capabilities. Many versions of 3DMark have been released since 1998. Scores cannot be compared across versions as each test is based on a specific version of the [[DirectX]] [[application programming interface|API]].{{cite web|url=http://www.futuremark.com/benchmarks/3dmarkvantage/whatis3dmark/|title=What is 3DMark?|work=Futuremark Corporation}} ==Versions== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Version !! Description !! Released !! Operating System !! style=white-space:nowrap | DirectX API !! Support Status |- valign="top" | 3DMark99 || The first 3DMark was one of the first 3D benchmarks to be aimed directly at the 3D gaming community, rather offering a generic overview of a PC's capabilities.{{cite web|title=Futuremark Corporation Releases 3DMark99|url=http://www.futuremark.com/pressroom/pressreleases/20408/|work=Futuremark Corporation|accessdate=24 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110324000000/http://www.futuremark.com/pressroom/pressreleases/20408/ |archivedate=2011-03-24}} The graphics tests use an early version of [[Remedy Entertainment]]'s MAX-FX engine, which was later used in the game [[Max Payne (video game)|Max Payne]]. | October 26, 1998 | Windows 95
Windows 98 | DirectX 6.0 | Discontinued after the release of 3DMark99 MAX |- valign="top" | 3DMark99 MAX || 3DMark99 MAX is a content update to 3DMark99.{{cite web|title=Futuremark Corporation Releases 3DMark99 MAX| url=http://www.futuremark.com/pressroom/pressreleases/20415/|date=1999-03-08|work=Futuremark Corporation|accessdate=2008-05-24|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110324000000/http://www.futuremark.com/pressroom/pressreleases/20415/ |archivedate=2011-03-24}} | March 8, 1999 | Windows 95
Windows 98 | DirectX 6.1 | Unsupported{{cite web|title=3DMark99 MAX download|url=http://www.futuremark.com/download/3dmark99max/|work=Futuremark Corporation|accessdate=24 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110324000000/http://www.futuremark.com/download/3dmark99max/ |archivedate=2011-03-24}} |- valign="top" | 3DMark2000 || The second generation 3DMark, making use of key features from DirectX 7 (such as hardware accelerated transform and lighting).{{cite web|url=http://www.futuremark.com/pressroom/pressreleases/20410/|title=MadOnion.com Releases 3DMark2000|date=1999-12-06|work=MadOnion.com|accessdate=2008-05-24}} The east and west are inverted in the games tests. {{cite web|url=http://futuremark.yougamers.com/forum/showthread.php?154565-The-world-of-MadOnion-was-not-the-same-as-Earth|title=The world of MadOnion was not the same as Earth.|date=2011-08-10|work=dddvantage}} | December 6, 1999 | Windows 95 Windows 98 Windows 98 SE Windows 2000 | DirectX 7 | Unsupported |- valign="top" | 3DMark2001 || The third generation 3DMark and the first 3D benchmark that supports DirectX 8, using key features such as vertex and pixel shaders, and point sprites.{{cite web|url=http://www.futuremark.com/pressroom/pressreleases/20414/ |title=MadOnion.com Releases 3DMark2001 |date=2001-03-13 |work=MadOnion.com |accessdate=2008-05-24 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080707053124/http://www.futuremark.com/companyinfo/pressroom/pressreleases/20414/ |archivedate=2008-07-07 |deadurl=no |df= }} | March 13, 2001 | Windows 98
Windows 98 SE
Windows ME
Windows 2000
Windows XP | DirectX 8.0 | Discontinued after the release of 3DMark2001 SE |- valign="top" | 3DMark2001 SE || 3DMark2001 Second Edition is an updated version of the third generation 3DMark2001 (the core benchmark tests are as in 3DMark2001, but there is an additional Feature test and broader hardware support).{{cite web|url=http://www.futuremark.com/pressroom/pressreleases/20394/ |title=MadOnion.com Releases 3DMark2001 Second Edition |date=2002-02-12 |work=MadOnion.com |accessdate=2008-05-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110930170119/http://www.futuremark.com/pressroom/pressreleases/20394/ |archivedate=September 30, 2011 }} 3DMark2001 SE is the last version of 3DMark to use the MAX-FX engine. | February 12, 2002 | Windows 98
Windows 98 SE
Windows ME
Windows 2000
Windows XP | DirectX 8.1 | Unsupported |- valign="top" | 3DMark03 || The fourth generation 3DMark. It is the first version that supports Microsoft DirectX 9.0 and introduces several new features. The graphics tests cover a range of rendering techniques and DirectX 9 features, expanding on a similar system used in 3DMark2001.{{cite web|url=http://www.futuremark.com/pressroom/pressreleases/20386/|title=3DMark03 Released|date=2003-02-11|work=Futuremark Corporation|accessdate=2008-05-24}} 3DMark03 does not use a 3rd party engine for any of the tests; light DirectX wrappers are used instead. The final score is a [[weighted sum]] of the game tests. The results of CPU and other tests are not taken into account.{{cite web|url=http://www.futuremark.com/pressroom/companypdfs/3dmark03_whitepaper.pdf|title=3DMark03 Whitepaper|date=2003-02-11|work=Futuremark Corporation|accessdate=2009-02-22}} As a complete package, 3DMark03 consists of: * 4 game tests: ** GT1: Wings of Fury - SM1.1 vertex shaders are used alongside fixed function pixel processing. ** GT2: Battle of Proxycon - SM1.1 vertex shaders / SM1.4 or 1.1 pixel shaders / stencil shadows ** GT3: Trolls' Lair - SM1.1 vertex shaders / SM1.4 or 1.1 pixel shaders / stencil shadows ** GT4: Mother Nature - SM1.x and SM2.0 vertex and pixel shaders * 2 CPU tests - low resolution versions of GT1 and GT3, using software vertex shaders to provide the CPU load * 4 Feature tests: ** Single and multi-texturing fill rate - fixed function rendering ** Vertex shader - SM1.1 vertex and pixel shaders ** Pixel shader 2.0 - procedural texturing ** Ragtroll - ragdoll physics and SM1.1 rendering * Sound tests - a sequence of graphics tests that uses 0, 24 and 60 sound sources | February 11, 2003 | style=white-space:nowrap | Windows 98
Windows 98 SE
Windows ME
Windows 2000
Windows XP | DirectX 9.0 | Unsupported |- valign="top" | 3DMark05 || The fifth generation 3DMark. Like 3DMark03, it is based on DirectX 9 but all of the graphics tests require a minimum hardware support of [[HLSL|Shader Model 2.0]].{{cite web|url=http://www.futuremark.com/pressroom/pressreleases/20402/|title=Futuremark Unveils 3DMark05|date=2004-09-29|work=Futuremark Corporation|accessdate=2008-05-24}} While the tests only make use of Shader Model 2.0, by default the highest compilation profile supported by the hardware is used, including 3.0. The final score is a [[geometric mean]] weighting the game tests equally. The CPU results are not taken into account.{{cite web|url=http://www.futuremark.com/pressroom/companypdfs/3DMark05_Whitepaper_v1_1.pdf|title=3DMark05 Whitepaper v1.1|date=2005-04-26|work=Futuremark Corporation}} In the free version only the part 1, "Return to Proxycon", of the demo is shown now.{{cite web|url=http://www.futuremark.com/support/3dmark05/|title=3DMark05 FAQ|work=Futuremark Corporation}} | style=white-space:nowrap | September 29, 2004 | Windows 2000
Windows XP (SP2) | DirectX 9.0(c) | Unsupported |- valign="top" | 3DMark06 || The sixth generation 3DMark.{{cite web|url=http://www.futuremark.com/pressroom/pressreleases/20407/ |title=Futuremark Overhauls "The Gamers' Benchmark" With 3DMark06 |date=2006-01-18 |work=Futuremark Corporation |accessdate=2008-05-24 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080501170207/http://www.futuremark.com/companyinfo/pressroom/pressreleases/20407/ |archivedate=2008-05-01 |deadurl=no |df= }} The three game tests, renamed "graphics tests", from 3DMark05 were carried over and updated, and a fourth new test "Deep Freeze" was added. The scoring formula was changed to incorporate CPU tests results: "For the first time in its history, the CPU result affects the final 3DMark score. This was done due to the fact that there are more and more games using complex AI algorithms and complex physics calculations."{{cite web|url=http://www.futuremark.com/pressroom/companypdfs/3DMark06_Whitepaper_v1_0_2.pdf|title=3DMark06 Whitepaper v1.0.2|date=2006-01-18|work=Futuremark Corporation|accessdate=2009-02-22}} Some of the graphics tests have the following features: * [[high dynamic range rendering|HDR rendering]] * [[Shadow mapping]] is used for all objects (specifically cascaded shadow mapping, with the depth textures filtered via hardware PCF) * Water surfaces are created using pixel shaders with [[HDR refraction]], [[HDR reflection]], [[depth fog]] and [[Gerstner wave functions]] * Atmospheric effects are generated via the use of heterogeneous fog, light scattering and cloud blending * Material surfaces use either [[Blinn-Phong shading model]] or [[Strauss lighting model]] and [[subsurface scattering]] in some cases The CPU tests in 3DMark06 are different from those found in previous 3DMark versions - instead of using software vertex shading to provide the CPU workload, path-finding, physics and engine routines are used instead, across multiple [[Thread (computer science)|thread]]s. The free version only show the part 1, "Return to Proxycon", of the demo. {{cite web|url=http://www.futuremark.com/products/3dmark06/features/|title=3DMark06 Advanced and Professional Features|work=Futuremark Corporation}} | January 18, 2006 | Windows XP
Windows Vista
Windows 7
Windows 8
Windows 8.1
Windows 10 | DirectX 9.0c | Unsupported |- valign="top" | style=white-space:nowrap | 3DMark Vantage || Futuremark released 3DMark Vantage on April 28, 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.futuremark.com/pressroom/pressreleases/52993/ |title=Futuremark Launches 3DMark Vantage |date=2008-04-28 |work=Futuremark Corporation |accessdate=2008-05-24 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080501171816/http://www.futuremark.com/pressroom/pressreleases/52993/ |archivedate=2008-05-01 |deadurl=no |df= }} It is a benchmark based upon DirectX 10, and therefore will only run under Windows Vista (Service Pack 1 is stated as a requirement) and Windows 7. Unlike all of the previous versions there is no demo mode in 3DMark Vantage. Initially the 3DMark Vantage range included a free trial which allowed a single run, the Basic Edition priced at US$6.95 and the Advanced Edition priced at US$19.95. On March 15, 2011 Futuremark released an update for 3DMark Vantage that discontinued the trial edition and made the Basic Edition free to download.{{cite news|title=3DMark Vantage Now More Compatible, Basic Version Free |url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2382000,00.asp |work=www.pcmag.com |accessdate=22 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110322000000/http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0%2C2817%2C2382000%2C00.asp |archivedate=2011-03-22 |first=Matthew |last=Murray |date=2011-03-15 |deadurl=yes }} | April 28, 2008 | Windows 10 Windows 8 Windows 7
Windows Vista | DirectX 10 | Unsupported |- valign="top" | 3DMark 11 || 3DMark 11 makes extensive use of all the new features in DirectX 11 including tessellation, compute shaders and multi-threading. It was released on December 7, 2010.{{cite web|url=http://futuremark.yougamers.com/forum/showthread.php?t=138723|title=Futuremark Confirms 3DMark 11 Release Date|date=2010-12-02|work=Futuremark Corporation|accessdate=2010-12-02}} 3DMark 11 includes four Graphics tests - Deep Sea 1 & 2, High Temple 1 & 2 - for measuring GPU performance, a Physics test measuring CPU performance, and a Combined test targeting CPU and GPU performance. 3DMark 11 includes a Demo that adds a soundtrack to the visual content. | December 7, 2010 | Windows 10
Windows 8.1
Windows 8
Windows 7
Windows Vista | style=white-space:nowrap | DirectX 11 | Supported |- valign="top" | 3DMark | Development of a new version of 3DMark was announced on 14 November 2011 with the final product, simply named 3DMark, released on February 4, 2013. Scores from Windows, Android and iOS can be compared making this version of 3DMark the first to enable cross-platform performance comparisons. Unlike previous versions, 3DMark features separate benchmark tests with each producing its own score. Ice Storm is a DirectX 11 feature level 9 / OpenGL ES 2.0 test targeting smartphones, tablets and entry-level PCs. Ice Storm Extreme is a variant of Ice Storm that uses more demanding settings to provide a suitable test for high-end mobile devices. Sling Shot is a mobile-only test introduced in March 2015 for Android and iOS, which is aimed at recent mobile devices and flagship phones. Cloud Gate is a DirectX 11 feature level 10 test for typical home PC and notebooks. Sky Diver is a DirectX 11 test aimed at gaming laptops and mid-range PCs that cannot achieve double-digit frame rates in the more demanding Fire Strike test. Fire Strike is a DirectX 11 test for gaming PCs. Fire Strike Extreme is a variant of Fire Strike used to test high-performance gaming PCs with multiple GPUs. Fire Strike Ultra is yet another variant of Fire Strike, which is meant to test enthusiast-grade PCs that are able to game at 4K resolution. Time Spy is a DirectX 12 test added in July 2016.{{cite web|title=INTRODUCING 3DMARK TIME SPY DIRECTX 12 BENCHMARK TEST|url=http://www.futuremark.com/pressreleases/introducing-3dmark-time-spy-directx-12-benchmark-test|accessdate=23 June 2016}} {{cite web|title=3DMARK TIME SPY - DIRECTX 12 BENCHMARK TEST AVAILABLE NOW|url=http://www.futuremark.com/pressreleases/3dmark-time-spy-directx-12-benchmark-test-available-now|accessdate=14 July 2016}} As it uses DirectX 12, which is only available in Windows 10, it only runs on Windows 10 but not older Windows OS versions. | February 4, 2013 (Windows)
April 2, 2013 (Android)
September 9, 2013 (iOS)
October 14, 2013 (Windows RT) | Windows Vista
Windows 7
Windows 8
Windows 8.1
Windows 10
Windows RT
Android
iOS | style=white-space:nowrap | DirectX 11 with
[[Direct3D#Feature levels | Direct 3D feature
levels]] 9, 10 and 11.
Time Spy test -
DirectX 12 with
feature level 11_0
supported | Supported |} == See also == * [[Benchmark (computing)]] * [[PCMark]] * [[Futuremark]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://www.3dmark.com 3DMark website] * [https://benchmarks.ul.com UL benchmarks] * [https://benchmarks.ul.com/legacy-benchmarks Unsupported benchmarks (3DMark99 MAX - Vantage)] {{DEFAULTSORT:3dmark}} [[Category:1998 software]] [[Category:Benchmarks (computing)]]

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=February 2016}}
The '''Aeronca Museum''' is an [[online museum]] that hosts a collection of artifacts and aircraft produced by '''[[Aeronca Aircraft|Aeronca]]''' (the '''Aeron'''autical '''C'''orporation of '''A'''merica) (a.k.a. Aeronca, Inc. or Aeronca Aircraft, now Magellan Aerospace Corp.) -- a prominent U.S. light aircraft manufacturer from 1928 to 1951. The museum is instituted to "preserve the knowledge and history of Aeronca aircraft in the public trust" and keep it "available for future generations," with the objective "to be the premier research library for all things Aeronca."<ref name="aeronca_museum_home">Aeronca Museum, [http://www.aeroncamuseum.org HOME page], Aeronca Museum website</ref><ref name="trainor_letter_2011_06">Trainor, Todd, Director, Aeronca Museum, [http://www.aeronca.com/aeronca_museum_letter.html letter] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120716192239/http://www.aeronca.com/aeronca_museum_letter.html |date=July 16, 2012 }}, June, 2011 on Aeronca.com</ref><ref name="rescuing_bomber_2013_04_21_livingston_daily">Totten, Jim, [https://www.warbirdsofglory.org/press/news_articles/livingston_daily_4-21-2013.pdf "Rescuing a WWII bomber in Alaska], ''Livingston [Mich.] Daily Argus & Reporter", 4-21-2013, PDF retrieved 2/27/2016.</ref> <ref name="aeronca_birth_2007_summer_aahs_journal">Harris, Richard, "[http://aahs-online.org/journals/journal_template.php?vol_no=v52n2 Aeronca: Birth of the Personal Plane]," ''AAHS Journal,'' Summer 2007, vol.52, #2, [[American Aviation Historical Society]]</ref> <ref name="aeronca_champion_history_2004_ifusa_harris">Harris, Richard, "[http://harris1.net/hold/av/avhist/anc/aeronca.htm Aeronca/Champion History: Beyond the Bathtub -- Chiefs, Champs & Citabrias]," from articles first appearing in ''In Flight USA,'' 2003-2004, condensed on author's website.</ref>
==History== The museum began its development under President and Executive Director Todd Trainor, an aircraft restoration specialist, long involved with Aeronca planes, <ref name="eaa_airventure_2014_presenter_todd_trainor" >EAA, [http://www.eaaapps.org/presenterinfo.aspx?id=460 "Todd Trainor, presenter"] EAA AirVenture 2014 Presenters, Airventure 2014 website [[Experimental Aircraft Association]], retrieved February 27, 2016.</ref> <ref name="trainor_seaplane_2010_07_10_antique_airfield">[http://www.antiqueairfield.com/articles/show/668-todd-trainor-s-aeronca-k-seaplane "Todd Trainor's Aeronca K Seaplane"], July 19, 2010, ''Antique Airfield'' website of [[Antique Airplane Association]] and the [[Airpower Museum]], retrieved February 27, 2016.</ref> <ref name="michigan_men_2013_04_04_fairbanks_daily_news_miner">Cole, Dermot, [https://www.warbirdsofglory.org/press/news_articles/newsminer_story_4-3-2013.pdf "Michigan men hope to recover WWII bomber southeast of Fairbanks"], 4/4/2013, ''Fairbanks Daily News-Miner,'' Fairbanks, Alaska, retrieved February 27, 2016.</ref>—and son of late Aeronca restoration expert Tom Trainor. <ref name="tom_trainor_obit">[http://deathnotices.michigan.com/view-single.php?id=102924&token= Trainor, Thomas Edison, obituary], 2006-02-21, ''The Detroit News and Detroit Free Press,'' retrieved 2016-02-28</ref>
A board was formed and the organization applied for 501(C)3 non-profit certification in early 2011; it holds that status, now, and is currently operating as a public information service.<ref name="trainor_letter_2011_06" />
At present, the artifacts are at the Museum's offices in [[Brighton, Michigan]], and in hangars at the [[Brighton Airport]], some undergoing restoration and preparation for presentation.<ref name="trainor_letter_2011_06" /><ref name="rescuing_bomber_2013_04_21_livingston_daily" />
Currently, the Museum largely serves as an archive of thousands of documents, drawings and blueprints, technical manuals and other research references related to Aeronca aircraft, and presents these online through its website, both commercially and as free-distribution information for Aeronca aircraft operators and enthusiasts.<ref name="trainor_letter_2011_06" />
==Exhibits and Artifacts== The Museum is home to "three complete [[Aeronca K]] projects (including one seaplane), one flyable [[Aeronca T|Aeronca TAC]], a [[Aeronca C-3|C-3]] basket case, and a [[Aeronca K|KCA]] basket case," some in restoration—and over 10,000 other Aeronca artifacts and papers.<ref name="trainor_letter_2011_06" />
The Museum has collected many documents, drawings, blueprints, manuals and other references from Aeronca, and from its successor, Magellan Aerospace, and from Aeronca enthusiasts, particularly those affiliated with the [[National Aeronca Association]] and the [[Fearless Aeronca Aviators]], and makes the available through its website, at [http://www.aeroncamuseum.org/ aeroncamuseum.org].
==See also== *[[Aeronca Aircraft]] *[[AIrventure Museum]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Links== *[http://www.aeroncamuseum.org/ Aeronca Museum] - official site *[https://web.archive.org/web/20141026112632/http://www.aeroncainc.com/history.html "Aeronca History" page], Aeronca, Inc. corporate website, (Aeronca's corporate website) [https://web.archive.org/web/20141026112632/http://www.aeroncainc.com/history.html] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20160113222310/http://www.aeronca.com/k/ The Aeronca K and Aeronca Engines website], (author/webmaster Todd Trainor) *[http://www.geocities.com/mrpeters.geo/Links.html Aeronca 11AC Chief Web site] *[http://www.aeroncapilots.com/ National Aeronca Association] *[http://www.aeronca.org/ Aeronca Aviators Club] *[http://aeronca.westmont.edu/aeronca/poobah/ Fearless Aeronca Aviators]
